title: Abstraction (Guitar and Glass)

thumbnail.alt_text: Geometric forms fragment a vertical composition containing a woodgrain table with newspapers, a guitar, and a stemmed wine glass. These objects are vividly painted within a V-shaped fragment at center. Muted, shadowlike versions of the objects appear outside it. The outline of the guitar is repeated in the V in brown, green, blue, and black alongside a fragment of brown floral wallpaper.

description: Juan Gris traveled to Paris in 1906 and soon moved to the neighborhood of Montmartre, where he met Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque. Eventually, Gris joined their artistic circle and participated in the development of Cubism. In Abstraction (Guitar and Glass), he incorporated objects often used in Cubist still-life painting—musical instruments, newspaper, a glass, and a tabletop. Rather than shatter their forms, however, Gris took a more synthetic approach to the composition. The overlapping planes, flattened appearance, and rhythmic patterns of the painting reinforce the two-dimensional nature of the picture’s surface, while the trompe l’oeil effects, deeply saturated colors, strong light-dark contrasts, and precise definition of forms give the still life an extraordinary physical reality.
inscriptions: Signed and dated on verso, u.l.: "Juan Gris 7-13"
credit_line: Charles H. and Mary F. S. Worcester Fund
publication_history:
Lang, L. Maurice, Annuaire des Ventes de tableaux, dessins, aquarelles, pastels, gouaches, miniatures 4 (October 1921–July 1922), p. 109, as La Guitare.

Art Institute, A Century of Progress: Exhibition of Paintings and Sculpture Lent from American Collections, exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute, 1933), p. 83 (cat. 775), as Abstraction, 1913.

Art Institute, A Century of Progress: Exhibition of Paintings and Sculpture Lent from American Collections, exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute, 1934), p. 52 (cat. 346), as Abstraction, 1913.

Jacques Seligmann and Company, Retrospective Loan Exhibition: Juan Gris (1887-1927), exh. cat. (New York: Jacques Seligmann and Company, 1938), n.p. (cat. 1, ill.), as Nature Morte a la Guitare, 1913.

Arts Club of Chicago, Retrospective Exhibition: Juan Gris (1887-1927), exh. cat. (Chicago: Arts Club, 1939), n.p. (cat. 23), as Nature Morte a la Guitare.

Arts Club of Chicago, Variety in Abstraction, exh. cat. (Chicago: Arts Club, 1946), n.p. (cat. 24), as Nature Morte a la Guitar, 1913.

Aznar, José Camón, “Juan Gris y sus Etapas,” Goya 3 (November–December 1954), p. 158 (fig. 3, ill.), as Guitarra y copa.

Aznar, José Camón, Picasso y el Cubismo (Madrid: Espasa-Calpe, 1956), p. 58 (fig. 26, ill.), as Guitarra y copa, 1913.

Hanzel Galleries, Chicago, Important Sale at Public Auction: The Renowned Etching Collection formed by the Late William T. Cresmer, The Collection of Paitntings formed by the Late Flora Schofield, also Paintings the Property of Mr. Arthur G. Levy, February 26, 1961, pp. 10 (lot 50), 17 (ill.), as Still Life with Guitar.

“Pay $36,000 for Work of Juan Gris,” Chicago Daily Tribune (February 27, 1961), p. A2, as Still Life with Guitar. 

Art Institute, Annual Report 1960–1961 (Chicago: Art Institute, 1961), n.p., cover (ill.), as Abstraction, 1913.

Speyer, A. James, “Twentieth-Century European Paintings and Sculpture,” Apollo 84, 55 (September 1966), p. 225 (pl. 9, ill.), as Abstraction, 1913.

Grung, Sandra, Supplement to Paintings in The Art Institute of Chicago: A Catalogue of the Picture Collection (Chicago: Art Institute, 1971), p. 47, as Abstraction (Still Life with Guitar), 1913.

Wood, James N., Treasures of 19th-and 20th-Century Painting: The Art Institute of Chicago (New York: Abbeville Press, 1993), p. 214 (ill.), as Guitar, Newspaper, and Glass, 1913.

provenance_text: The artist; Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler (1884–1979), Paris, 1913 [letter from Maurice Jardot of Galerie Louise Leiris, Aug. 1976, in curatorial file]; sold, Hôtel Drouot, Paris, 3rd Kahnweiler sequestration sale, July 4, 1922, lot 98, as La Guitare. Flora Schofield (1873-1960), Chicago, by 1927 [Hanzel Galleries 1961]; sold, Hanzel Galleries, Chicago, Feb. 26, 1961, lot 50, to the Art Institute of Chicago.
